That was fascinating. Fun fact about methyl groups. If you strip one hydrogen from Methane, CH4, you get CH3, a methyl group. Petrochemical plants can do that but because it creates excess hydrogen that has to be flared they split (crack) Ethane, C2H6, into two methyl groups. Add an OH to a methyl group and you get methanol. Methyl groups are the building blocks for nearly everything that modern society uses, including the computer, the chips that make the computer and electronics in general work, the internet, wire coating, cars.,.. you name it... it's daddy or mamma, you pick, is a methyl group. Running out of fossil fuels has much, much larger ramifications for society than just fuel.

This presentation is wrong:
Both men and women have Blaschko's lines invisibly.
But most dsorders, that make the Blaschko's lines *visible*, are linked to the X chromosome.

- Some of these disorders, which are X-linked dominant are lethal in males, which is why the there is only female calico cats.
And others are not lethal, and so found in both sexes.
- While others are X-chromosome *recessive*. Women with only one such disordered x-chromosome, will be only carriers because of their healthy X-chromosome.
While men who gets that disordered x-chromosome, will always have the disorder.
So boys and girls are different 🤯

In your overly short bit about epigenetics, you failed to mention that a human can, within the lifetime of a single organism, mutate enough so that some of even the more base genetic features are permanently altered, which can reflect in their progeny. This has been seen multiple times, especially in monogamous couples who have children up to a decade apart. One very good example is skin adaptation to sun exposure. A young, very pale couple has a child that is also very pale. After 15 years of continuous sun exposure and their genetic make up mutating to protect their skin (getting a tan) their youngest progeny have a much higher chance of inheriting this modified trait and, as a result, the youngest child would be far less pale than its eldest sibling by comparison.

What i learned is that :
-humans are diploid (2 copies of the same DNA except the x and y chromosomes for the man) .
-the expression of genes is ruled by the interactions between the 2 copies : domination/recessivity, additivity...etc. and not the whole chromosome of a parent la not expressed ,just some of them .
-for the majority of phenotypes (for example :the colour of the skin), there are more than one gene controlling it .

conclusion:
1) there are some faults in this video that should be corrected .
2)I encourage you to continue your work , you have very interesting things to say.
3)epigenetics exists , you can demonstrate it simply by the differences between twins.

I wouldn’t say the behavior of our ancestors influences our epigenetic expression as much as the physical locations, societal conditions and social constructs within which they lived. A good example is how we can see the health effects of generations of systemic and institutional racism manifested in the statistically poorer birth outcomes for black mothers in America, who are more at risk of: 

- having babies with low birth weights; 
- pre-term labor and premature birth; 
- being subject to the blatant racial biases of healthcare workers during appointments (i.e. pervasive myths that black women have higher pain tolerances, dismissive attitudes from doctors leading to late intervention care, misdiagnosis, or a lack of diagnosis altogether); 
- or even being more likely to endure the legacy of physical consequences that racist urban planning practices can have (such as redlining, where black people were barred from buying homes in desirable neighborhoods and forced to live in neighborhoods more exposed to industry, or even municipal neglect in the case of the water supply in Flint, Michigan).

All of these things aren’t really about behavior and choices so much as a nebulous web of systems and traumas affecting black mothers on a physiological level for generations.

The use of the word "stripey" in relation to calico cats is a little misleading. Tabby cats (or any cat with the agouti gene) can be male or female. Tabby itself is a striped pattern and not related to color.

Being calico or tortoiseshell means having orange and black/brown and possibly white patches. Those different colors can sometimes look "stripey" as shown in the video. And indeed, most calico/tortoiseshell cats are female. Although in rare cases there are male cats with 2 X chromosomes which allows them to exhibit this coloration. But such genetic anomalies are often fatal or result in infertility.

It's not weird that epigenetics changes as we have lived experiences, it actually makes a lot of sense if you want an organism which is adaptive in its own lifespan without the need to adjust genes only during sex (where the typical randomization takes process and evolution acts on it here). Basically, an organism which doesn't change can't change to better suit its environment and take on behaviours which may be beneficial to that organism's survival chances during its lifespan.

Flexibility is a very useful ability, and humans are pretty good at assessing and predicting which risks are bad and which risks are good. It is because situations are relativisitic in life that you'd expect evolution to produce an organism better capable of taking advantage of opportunities that present themselves situationally.

An extremely rigid system may even make less sense in a changing world.

XX and XY is not sufficient to explain sex, as those with XX chromosomes may produce sperm, and those with XY chromosomes can produce female ovum. There is even XX male syndrome, but if chromosomes alone were enough to determine sex, they would be female anyway. It's more complicated than which chromosome you have. The X and Y chromosomes typically carry specific sex determining genes which affect development in a typical person. If you edit the genes within, for example in the Y chromosome, you can change the result to female whilst still being just a Y chromosome.

The content of those genes and the sex characteristics which result are more precise when determining sex.

Epigenetic theory is somewhat in contradiction to Darwinian evolution theory. One of the sacred ideas of Darwinian evolution is that genes change due to random mutation and nothing you do in life changes what you hand down to the next generation. Lamarckian evolution was rejected because he thought that what a species does while active influences the course of evolution. In other words, if members of a species add behaviors due to environmental stresses, such as more mental activity in certain ways, then that directly speeds up the evolution of certain kinds of intelligence being handed down.

You just solved a mystery for me that I've been carrying since junior college. We had been told that the deactivation of X chromosomes was totally random across cells. Then we were given a test question that went something like this: "In a certain japanese cat race, only female cats can be bicolor. Male bicolor cats do occur but are very rare. Explain this phenomenon." The answer they wanted to hear of course was that they were Klinefelter Cats with the genetic formula XXY. But I immediately protested saying that if the deactivation of an X chromosome is totally random, that would work out in a mixed color, not distinct spots. My teacher didn't know how to respond and ended up saying that the question was probably wrong. That was more than 20 years ago. Thanks for clearing that up.

The comment about a cat's coat color being on the sex chromosomes bothered me though. You're not entirely wrong, but you're also not right. The color RED is determined by sex chromosomes, all other colors are on other genes. Since male cats can only have a single X, that X will either be Red or Not Red, meaning you'll either end up with an all red male, or a male of a non-red color. But in females, since they have two X's, they can either have two Reds, meaning a red female cat, two Not Reds, meaning a non-red cat, or a Red and a Non Red, which results in a calico pattern for the reasons you described. Colors that you can have that aren't red are Black, Chocolate, or Cinnamon, and you can get other colors when those base colors are diluted either by the dilution gene, pointed gene, or any kind of tabby gene. There's more to it but that's too much for this XD

Actually, it isn't true that xx = female and xy = male. There are several other factors involved in sex, including hormones, secondary sex characteristics, and so forth. Someone can have XY chromosomes but have Androgen Suppression Syndrome, which will makes them appear more feminine, develop breasts and female genitalia, but the individual will be missing a uterus. This is just one item from a long list of intersex conditions.

4:20 That definition of "epigenetics" is too simplified, to the point where it's actually false. Makes it sound like an environmental factor, or a single event, could be considered an epigenetic factor.
As you explained, DNA is never bare inside the cell; there are loads of proteins and some RNA on it (the whole structure is called "chromatin"). An epigenetic process is a phenomenon that occurs on this whole, affecting gene expression without changing the sequence of it.
Another interesting detail, these changes (usually modifications of the histones, even methylation directly on the DNA) are semi-permanent. There are enzymes to undo them, but otherwise they're copied along with the DNA itself during divisions, allowing them to get passed down the generations.

Epigenetics describes the process of methylation(usually) bindings which "hide" certain parts of your DNA.  If a certain loop of DNA is demethylated by certain environmental stresses, then that loop is open and activated.  The methylation sites are passed on in cell reproduction (including gametes(sex cells)).

genes in general do not change except during meiosis when chromosomes randomize slightly, however the raw gene itself does not control everything that an individual grows into. external factors are a major contributor as well.  chromosomal maleness and femaleness do not change with today's level of technology, however external factors can change the phenotype and gene expression of a person, which are what individuals will encounter daily.  hence, chromosomal sex is only relevant when considering reproductive fertility of mating pairs (and in rare cases, excess chromosomes that cause certain syndromes), and otherwise is irrelevant.

There is one kind of technical inaccuracy that I love pointing out when people bring up the fact that all calico cats are female. There is such a thing as a male calico cat, but they are always sterile. They have an intersex condition where their chromosomes are XXY. This can happen to humans to; it's called Klinefelter syndrome. People who have it do look like typical males, but in humans and cats it causes sterility.

Anyway, awesome video. It's just fun to bring that up because the idea of a male with a double X chromosome blows people's minds.

Not to be too much of a pain, but to be Calico, a cat doesn't have to be female, it just has to have two X chromosomes. Genetic abnormalities can produce XXY kitties (XXXY, etc.) who are, by virtue of their Y chromosomes, male. And female XO (one X, no Y) kitties are female, but cannot be Calicos. <3

So I was thinking about this years ago when I heard about Lyonisation. My thoughts were like this: If we ever get body replacements going they will either have to be either somewhat generic or otherwise only available to males, and only males that aren't genetic chimeras at that.

Because it would be extremely difficult to recreate the patterns of X chromosome inactivation, which might well have an effect. For instance, lets say one patch of your brain that has your artistic ability has the X chromosome active that say increases your artistic ability somehow. You are an artist and that is part of your identity. But you get a new body, but somehow your new body has the brain part for artistic ability with the other X chromosome active, and that one has no special ability. So you lose your artistic ability. This could happen with anything, like personality, whatever. What do you think?

PS: I know this is a gross oversimplification, but the point is the process I describe still could change brain chemistry to the point where it would change your personality or intelligence or any other personal trait.

Charles Darwin admitted that, "If it could be demonstrated that any complex organ existed, which could not possibly have been formed by numerous, successive, slight modifications, my theory would absolutely break down." On the subject of calico cats, I actually raised a couple of male calicos. They were sterile, and never had kittens, which makes sense when you consider how their unique situation must have occurred: they were XXY mutants. They still had the coloring dispersal thanks to the X vs X deactivation, but that pesky Y contributed to the formation of male gonads. Due to the presence of 2 X chromosomes, the Y chromosomes genes were partially drowned out, and the males never had effective reproductive systems. This would be a great jumping off point to discuss Klinefelter and Non-Klinefelter syndrome, where this XXY arrangement occurs in humans.

Epigenetics is not just related to chromosome activity but to developmental biology as well: by itself, epigenetics is the branch of molecular genetics that studies the changes in gene expression, whether it's due to gene expression regulation pathways (e.g. gene expression regulated by hormone levels) or due to environmental changes.

That said, what Derek says is absolutely right: epigenetic markers (not methylation, but I'm not going into detail, although there are some other markers) can be conserved for a few generations (to children and grandchildren), thus making our own epigenetics dependent of our ancestors' behaviour and environment. But our own behaviour and environment further affects epigenetics when we grow up, and therefore, the affirmation is only valid (under this premise) for cases such as X-chromosome inactivation in women, because it's only in our earliest stages in life (as an embryo or a fetus) that our ancestors' markers are still more relevant than those imposed by our own environment. 

Nevertheless, there's something deeper to take into account here. Recent trends in research point that epigenetic marking may sometimes modify recombination likelihood and patterns, as well as change the activity of repeating sequences in the DNA. That is, epigenetic marking can cause modifications in the original sequence, thus becoming a permanent (fixed) modification in the genetic information, rather than it being just an expression pattern. The concept of ancestors behaviour and environment affecting the genetic sequences of an individual is a very risky idea. Gorgeous, but risky: those who are bravest name it "neolamarckism".

So someone who eats a wide variety of natural foods would produce offspring whose RNA is able to interpret and execute DNA coding with much more fidelity; likewise, someone who subsides on a narrow diet of heavily-processed foods may not be providing the essential nutrients to his or her body.  As a result of the narrow and heavily-processed diet the body doesn't have the necessary proteins readily available for RNA execution of DNA coding, and expressions of genes can be altered.  If I'm not mistaken epigenetics tells us if a trend of environmental factors is repeated over enough generations, then the actual DNA code can be altered on a much more permanent basis.
Hypothetically (let me just take this and run with it) let's look at a frozen dinner from Wal-Mart that is devoid of an essential protein "X," but it's so cheap that not buying lots of it is not an option.  Now if grandma ate a disproportionately large amount of these meals before procreating, and if mom ate a similarly disproportionate amount of those meals before procreating, then the child's DNA coding, which demands protein "X" could have been switched off because the necessary nutrient wasn't available to carry it out in previous generations?
So thanks to epigenetics DNA is a bit like "use it or lose it" paid time off at work:  If you don't provide the right nutrients, then DNA coding will eventually become obsolete.  What if that DNA coding were really important?  What if, say, it's a code that instructs the pancreas to regulate and sustain insulin levels in the body?
Or is it a bit gauche to suggest that parents and grandparents are responsible in certain cases of childhood diabetes?
Or is it a bit insensitive to suggest that a cheap and convenient diet, (despite how heavily processed and nutritionally narrow it may be) which is well within everyone's personal responsibility to avoid, is worse than taking the time to cook proper meals for your family?

About the calico cats, it is actually possible for there to be male calico cat; however, it is the result of a non-dis-junction in cell division during oogenesis or spermiogenesis. Where an extra sex-chromosome is present in either the dominant egg cell or the fertilizing sperm cell. This is referred to as Trisomy-23 where the possible combinations are (XXY) (XXX) (XYY). (XXY) or Klinefelters-Syndrome is when a male has an extra X-chromosome and the phenomenon viewed in this video occurs. Resulting in a striped male cat.

Excuse me, sir, but telling people that "women are stripey" is a tremendous lie. Epigenetics means we "silence" a chromosome thanks to metilations/acetilations. On women, at 32-weeks on the embryonary state they "choose" which one of the 2 X chromosomes are silenced. If you keep the X chromosome coming from your dad mute, then every cell will express the X chromosome from your mom (which is not silenced). Therefore, women are not stripey.

Anyway, about the cats: I don't really know which chemical epigenetic methods they use (I think they are the same as in humans), but the fascinating thing about it is that their genes behave like the Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome does: by expressing both alleles randomly chosen in the embryonic state. Maybe they express both because their "hair colour" alleles behave like they have an extreme "expression power" so they don't even work with Mendelian laws or they even can't be metilated (silenced).

TL;DR: The title is a lie, pls explain more.

I have a question: Do you think selective breeding may work with any epigenetic mechanism? Like how you can make dogs smaller by only breeding the small ones.

I wrote a paper in High School about how there must be an epigenetic mechanism that aids evolutionary changes. I was talking about epigenetics, but didn't know what to call it at the time. My teacher insisted that I was wrong, and that the only way a genome could change was through random mutations to the coding.
I believe that the chemistry of DNA could have evolved to become more pliable to changes with a bottle neck in the population that favours certain traits; setting off a reaction to make future generations more likely to exhibit phenotypic traits outside of the previous population. 
It was my postulation that there was ample evidence to suggest that the chemistry of DNA has evolved to produce a mechanism that can favour certain genetic changes over others. One example I gave was the selective breeding of corn crops in the USA during the early 20th century to produce corn with higher levels of oil than was previously seen in the genome of the corn they were working with. I postulated that by creating a bottle-neck effect in the population that  selected for individuals with higher oil content, after a few generations, the genetics had been changed by an epigenetic process that created genes now switched on for higher oil content. This example took a mere 5 years from what I remember.

A traditional genetic understanding would say that the selection had favoured higher oil content and random mutation had created the change that made oil content higher than in the previous population.

I have always believed that continued selective forces, like for higher oil content or smaller dogs, could create a tag on certain genes to make them more pliable to more change in that direction. This is an easy explanation for how these changes can come about in such a short number of generations.

Maybe I'm way off with this; I'm just not really sure because I don't know if this question has been addressed yet by the scientific community.

This is because most of Lamarck's arguments were mainly influenced by environmental factors and even now have no clear epigenetic link i.e. Blacksmith's and their children in terms of muscle size. Epigenetics is a fascinating field and for anyone that would like to delve into it a little further I would really recommend 'The Epigenetics Revolution' by Nessa Carey.

It's particularly interesting how X-inactivation results in variable effects in all X-Linked genetic abnormalities in carrying women. For the most part only males are affected, but because x-inactivation is random, carrying women are occasionally affected. The epigenetic changes are particularly interesting as well. On the paternal side most of the effects are encoded in the pre-pubertal (age 10-12) period, meaning that your father's decisions during that short period of time will have major effects on the expression of your genes. Very cool subject.

Interesting fact:

Because of epigenetics, if you had a set of identical twins, and separated them at birth, sent one to live on one side of the planet, and the other on the other, in 2 vastly different cultures and families; if you then brought them back together, they would look nothing alike, despite being identical twins

Their epigenetics were influenced by the environment they grew up in, and as such the identical twins would end up look different.
